section.title: Introduction
section.para: This page holds answers to questions specifically about the Sloan Digital Sky Survey. Several other sites have answers to general astronomy questions, including the sci.astro FAQ and the Curious about Astronomy? site at Cornell University.

question.para: What does the SDSS logo represent?

answer.para: The Sloan Survey's goal is to image one-half of the northern celestial hemisphere (one quarter of the total sky), as well as a smaller portion of the southern sky. The portion of the universe that the survey will observe is represented by our vaguely parachute-shaped logo. We are at the center of the logo, at the vertex of the parachute strings. The elliptical background evokes the shape of a galaxy, the celestial object of greatest interest to the Sloan Survey.
Because the total solid angle (area) of the survey will be 10,000 square degrees, or pi steradians, the logo is sometimes jokingly referred to as "pi on the sky".

question.para: Can I download/use the images from the SDSS site?

listitem.para: You must maintain the image credits if you publish or reproduce the image for any purpose other than personal enjoyment.
You must not use the image in such a way as to imply endorsement for a product or service.
If you reproduce these images on a web page, we ask that you provide a link back to our site.

answer.para: More detailed information can be found on the credits page.

question.para: Who is the "Sloan" in the Sloan Digital Sky Survey?

answer.para: The "Sloan" refers to the Alfred P. Sloan Foundation, one of the major funding sources of the survey. You can learn about Mr. Sloan and his philanthropic foundation at http://www.sloan.org. More information about all the members of the survey is also available on our site.

question.para: The SDSS Query Analyzer (SDSSQA) used to work, but now it doesn't any more. How can I fix it?

answer.para: In general, the use of sdssQA is deprecated. The CasJobs interface: http://casjobs.sdss.org/CasJobs/, is a better tool for most purposes.

If you really want to use the SDSS QA, there are a few things you can do. Begin by removing the existing installation. When you are certain that no instances of sdssQA are running, delete the .sdssQA directory, probably found in your home directory. Then reinstall sdssQA using the latest jar file from
the sdssQA page.

question.para: How can I query for specific types of galaxies?

answer.para: You have several options, none of them perfectly reliable. One of these the eclass field, described in section 4.10.2.4 of the early data release paper and in the algorithms section of the data release pages..
